stories.header: The Pulse Of The Customer
stories.summary: - What is really telling is that our customers see us as extremely knowledgeable. They trust our judgement and they trust our opinion and knowledge when it comes to PR and how to work with PR in the Mynewsdesk newsroom, Tina Lindahl, Mynewsdesk Head of Retention, says and refers to the fresh customer survey she carried out in Sweden this spring.
stories.body:
- What is really telling is that our customers see us as extremely knowledgeable. They trust our judgement and they trust our opinion and knowledge when it comes to PR and how to work with PR in the Mynewsdesk newsroom, Tina Lindahl, Mynewsdesk Nordic Head of Customer Retention, says and refers to the fresh customer survey she carried out in Sweden this spring.

Why a customer survey?
The purpose of the customer survey is to get an understanding of general behavior as well as future expectations of customers.

- We felt a need to get a better understanding of our customers, of the product usage, of the product experience and how the clients perceive us as a supplier, Tina explains. We’ve interviewed around a hundred customers across all subscriptions and time spent with us. The reason why we chose Sweden to start with is that it’s our biggest market.

In the video below, Tina Lindahl talks about how the survey was conducted, the opportunities we see for the future and the plans to follow up on the findings.



Customers don’t know what to expect from us
-The result of the survey identifies two big challenges that clients in general have, Maja Lindström, Chief Product Officer at Mynewsdesk, says. The main challenge is to reach out: to get through the noise and to create something that reaches the intended audience. The other challenge is time.

She continues:
- The results also show that customers seem to find it difficult to define what Mynewsdesk is. When being asked “What would you expect from a service like Mynewsdesk?”, they don’t really know what to say or expect. And they don’t know what the alternatives are.

- That is a challenge, but it’s also an opportunity. We can be much better in our messaging and how we talk about ourselves to define what kind of market we are in.

Next steps
- The new survey result confirms what we’ve learned from other studies and customer interviews, and also corresponds well to what we’ve put in our product roadmap, Maja declares, so we'll continue to execute on that. Another action that I would like to see happen is that our local teams in other markets also perform the survey, so that we can see if there are similarities or differences, and if the same challenges apply to all our customers.

The results
All Mynewsdesk employees may access the complete results of the survey on our shared Drive. Please go to *MNDDocs/Projects/Customer Survey_Sweden May 2014

stories.header: Daniel Believes In The Perfect World. #MNDimpact
stories.summary: - When Mynewsdesk announced that all staff had the opportunity to choose an organisation to work with within our Social Innovation project, the choice was simple, Daniel Wilke says. I had just returned from Zambia and I had seen how serious the situation is for some animals. That’s why I offered The Perfect World Foundation a free newsroom along with my personal support for the coming year.
stories.body:
For little more than a year ago, Daniel Wilke, account manager at our Gothenburg office, was planning a trip to Africa to see the wildlife. At the same time, by what seems to be a lucky turn of fate, he met Lars and Ragnhild Jacobsson in an elevator. The couple turned out to run a non-profit organisation called The Perfect World Foundation, aimed to fight the poaching of endangered animals. The three of them quickly became friends and the couple helped Daniel to plan his African trip, while he in return helped them with advice on how to raise awareness of the poaching to the public.

An easy choice
- When Mynewsdesk announced that all staff had the opportunity to freely choose an organisation to work with for a year within our Social Innovation project, the choice was simple, Daniel says. I had just returned from Zambia where I was working as a volunteer to help lions, cheetahs and elephants and I had seen how serious the situation is for some animals. For example, Zambia only had 11 rhinos left! I was determined that I wanted to help and make a difference. That’s why I offered The Perfect World Foundation a free newsroom along with my personal support for the coming year.

The need for buzz
To stop the poaching of rhinos, lions, elephants and other rare animals, the organisation have a huge need to raise money but also attention.

- In order to get that, we started to plan Sweden’s first fundraising gala dinner for animals, Daniel explains. With the help of some amazing people and their networks, Mynewsdesk as a PR-tool and generous sponsors, we managed to create ”buzz” around the gala. It helped us to fill the guest list with famous names of artists, performers, actors, politicians and even royalty.

Daniel and The Perfect World Foundation are now looking forward to the event that will take place the 18th of September at Hotel Post in Gothenburg.

The kind of help given to the organisation
Daniel’s role is to manage the newsroom for the organisation. He writes press releases, contacts media and fills the newsroom with content. He is also responsible for the gala, to invite the media and present the celebrities to journalists. He has also helped to find and recruit some of the celebrity ambassadors and sponsors who has helped in various ways.

- Right now, I probably spend 8-10 hours per week in my spare- or lunchtime working with the gala preparations, he says. But normally, I put in one or two hours per week. Feeling very strongly about this cause, I feel it’s worth every minute of my time.

About the photo: The cheetah in the picture is a rescued animal. 

*Tweet this article with the hashtag #MNDimpact*

stories.header: Mynewsdesk employees take the bike to deliver a key 500 km away
stories.summary: Crazy, innovative, healthy - that’s some of the things that defines the Mynewsdesk company culture. With that in mind, it’s nothing peculiar about a 500 kilometer bike ride to mark the opening of Mynewsdesk’s new Trondheim office next week.
stories.body:
Crazy, innovative, healthy - that’s some of the things that defines the Mynewsdesk company culture. With that in mind, it’s nothing peculiar about a 500 kilometer bike ride to mark the opening of Mynewsdesk’s new Trondheim office next week.

Members of the Oslo crew and the NHST group CEO Gunnar Björkavåg, decided to deliver the key to the new office themselves. As we at Mynewsdesk don’t own any company cars, but some environmental friendly company bikes, the vehicle was given.

The bike ride starts in Oslo on Sunday and the participants are expected to arrive in Trondheim on Wednesday next week. Regional manager in Trondheim, Erlend Nordbak, is looking forward to greet his former Oslo colleagues when they arrive.
- Together with new clients and partners, we’ll throw them a fantastic welcoming party, he says.

Follow and share the ride on social media. Look out for the hashtag #mybikeride.

stories.header: "People Like To Work With People Who Challenge Them A Bit"
stories.summary:
Heather Athie was awarded Mynewsdesker Of The Year in January. The special grounds defined by the jury are:

For creating the Account Management, Retention and Customer Success team in one of Mynewsdesk's most challenging markets and getting results. Heather combines engagement, insight and humour which makes both her customers and her colleagues delighted.
stories.body:
Heather Athie, Account Director at Mynewsdesk in London, was awarded Mynewsdesker Of The Year in January. The special grounds defined by the jury are:

For creating the Account Management, Retention and Customer Success team in one of Mynewsdesk's most challenging markets and getting results. Heather combines engagement, insight and humour which makes both her customers and her colleagues delighted.

See for yourself that those words are really true. View the video below where Heather describes the surprise and excitement she felt upon getting a text message from a colleague telling her she’d won. Prepare yourself to be enchanted by Heather’s strong and charming personality. Feel good vibes guaranteed!

A Mynewsdesk journey
- I started at Mynewsdesk almost three years ago. I was part of the very small team that kind of launched it in London, which was really exciting, Heather says.

- Since then we’ve grown and been through a lot of changes, she adds. It’s been really fascinating, because trying to adapt to a new market and to find the right product-market fit is demanding yet really interesting. So it’s been both challenging and rewarding for me to be part of this journey.

In the next video, Heather talks about the current retention focus she’s working on in London, gives her view on what's the key to success and explains why it’s important to be part of a great team.

stories.header: Mynewsdesk Launches Digital Heroes - An Executive Training Program For Brand Builders In The New Era
stories.summary: After an intense 3-month period of hard work, analysis and preparation, Mynewsdesk in collaboration with the strategy firm Global Focus are happy to introduce the project Digital Heroes, an executive training program for marketing and brand managers. The program will first launch in Sweden this fall.
stories.body:
After an intense 3-month period of hard work, analysis and preparation, Mynewsdesk in collaboration with the strategy firm Global Focus are happy to introduce the project Digital Heroes, an executive training program for marketing and brand managers. The program will first launch in Sweden this fall.

-The project has been a secret for a very long time, and I’m happy to finally be able to talk about it, Rebecca Cannerfelt, Project Manager for Digital Heroes at Mynewsdesk, says. Watch the video below where she shares her enthusiasm for the project and reveals the details about the Digital Heroes executive training.

Why digital heroes?
-We define a digital hero as a person who unleash the superpowers of their brand to create social engagement in the new era, Rebecca says. People who do the right things in the digital world creates incredible advantage for their companies and often receive much attention and praise within their businesses and sectors. The Digital Heroes training program will help more people to understand how the digitalization affects themselves, their company and the world around them. 

Learn more
Global Focus and Mynewsdesk both work with brand development and communication, Global Focus from a strategic perspective and Mynewsdesk on a more operative level. From our different viewpoints, we’ve developed a training program with an overall approach to brand engagement in the new era. The project group consists of the following people:

  • Pär Lagerström, COO Nordics, Mynewsdesk
  • Rebecca Cannerfelt, Project Manager, Mynewsdesk
  • Arne Forstenberg, CEO, Global Focus
  • Olof Ålenius, Partner och Strategy Director, Global Focus
  • Lotta Murvall, Consultant, Global Focus

There are also key Mynewsdeskers assisting the project such as Anton Jarl (on design), Sofia Juhlin, Sarah Rundt and Matilda Agné (marketing).  

From August Gabriella Sjödin will also join the team as a Project Manager, with a strong focus on sales.

For more information, please visit the Digital Heroes web site or some of the social channels (in Swedish only).

Newsroom
Twitter
Facebook
LinkedIn

stories.header: Mynewsdesk Opens A New Office In Trondheim
stories.summary: Erlend Nordbak, currently working in our Oslo office, will be responsible for the new Trondheim office that opens in Trondheim later this summer. Erlend, who has worked as a Team Manager in Oslo for almost two years, is looking forward to his new challenge. As Regional Manager in Trondheim, he will be responsible for bringing Mynewsdesk to the north of Norway.
stories.body:
Erlend Nordbak will be responsible for the new Trondheim office that opens in Trondheim later this summer. Erlend, who has worked as a Team Manager in Oslo for almost two years, is looking forward to his new challenge. As Regional Manager in Trondheim, he will be responsible for bringing Mynewsdesk to the north of Norway.

- Trondheim is the technology hub in Norway where established players as well as exciting startup businesses co-exist, says Henriette Sveen, Country Manager at Mynewsdesk Norway. Therefore, it’s a logical step that the first office outside Oslo would be located in this kind of environment.

Top reasons why we chose Trondheim for the Norwegian expansion:

  • Many small-medium businesses with the need to simplify communication processes.
  • Tech oriented environment with a low threshold for new tech solutions.
  • Strong growth in the Oslo area that has the potential to spill over even up north.
  • Strengthen our position by local presence.
Pär Lagergren, COO Nordics, is positive to discuss even further office openings over the next year.

- We might open up even more offices in Norway, he says and points at Bergen and Stavanger as future potential cities for the expansion. The new office in Trondheim demonstrates that the Mynewsdesk success story continues, he adds, and also that there is a need to pair a digital product with the human touch. Good relations have always been the key to success in the Nordics, and it seems to continue that way.

stories.header: Mynewsdesk's Social Innovation Project Supports The Urban Gardener. #plantsomeshit
stories.summary: #plantsomeshit. That's the hashtag for, and also summarizes, what Urban Gardener Ron Finley does to change the world. When he visited Stockholm a month back to talk at the EAT Forum, Harrie Rademaekers, our Chief Arts Officer, got the opportunity to meet him. One thing led to another and Harrie decided to take on Ron's project as his social innovation organisation.
stories.body:
#plantsomeshit. 

That's the hashtag for, and also summarizes, what Urban Gardener Ron Finley does to change the world. He is not a man who will sit still and watch a problem grow. Being brought up in the South Los Angeles food desert, Ron is familiar with the area’s lack of fresh produce. He knew what it’s like to drive 45 minutes just to get a fresh tomato. In 2010, he set out to fix the problem. Outside his front door, that is. Ron planted vegetables in the curbside dirt strip next to his home. And quietly, carefully, tenderly started a revolution. 

On Ron’s website you can read more about how he was cited for gardening without a permit on Los Angeles parkways, but how he fought back with the help of green activists, and eventually forced the city to back off.

Mynewsdesk will help to spread the word
When Ron visited Stockholm a month back to talk at the EAT Forum, alongside celebrities such as Bill Clinton and the Prince of Wales, Harrie Rademaekers, our Chief Arts Officer, got the opportunity to meet him. One thing led to another and Harrie decided to take on Ron's project as his social innovation organisation. 

Watch the video below to hear the amazing story where Harrie tells us how he first became impressed by Ron's TED talk online and then realized they were connected through a mutual friend. A few months on, they've now got the chance to learn from each other within the frameworks of Mynewsdesk's Social Innovation Project. 

Next steps
- The plan for the nearest future is to set up Ron's newsroom, to get him and his crew educated on how to work with it and to support him whatever he needs to make it work properly, Harrie says. Furthermore we can look into future possibilities regarding relevant events to participate in on our different markets. Ron will from his side provide us with behind the scenes material and special meet and greet events with our clients when he is visiting any of the countries where we have a Mynewsdesk office.

Learn more
Ron Finley is a man of many qualities. If you want to read more on his way to stardom have a look at this piece on him from The NY Times.

And, of course, watch his famous TED Talk which has been viewed over two million times already.


More updates on the Ron Finley project will follow.

stories.header: We’ve Put Together An Awesome Team For The SanFranPlan Project!
stories.summary: The hard work to put together a perfect SanFranPlan Project Team is now done, and we’re ready to announce which ones have been selected to create the most amazing field trip to San Francisco for the entire company.
stories.body:
The hard work to put together a perfect SanFranPlan Project Team is now done, and we’re ready to announce which ones have been selected to create the most amazing field trip to San Francisco for the entire company.

The lucky few are... (Click for drumroll!)

  • Robert Stark (Stockholm)
  • Ben van Leeuwen (London)
  • James Bull (London)
  • Daniel Wilke (Gothenburg)
  • Johan Höjvall (Stockholm)
  • Cathrine Formoe (Oslo)
  • Emma Larsen (Stockholm)

Why we picked these people (and not you)
Some of the team members will primarily focus on contributing with their professional competence in certain areas (Robert-finance, Emma-travel etc), but they all need to take an active part in planning this trip everything taken into account.
- We need creative ideas but all of the members have been picked because we know that they also can put ideas into action....or make shit happen, if you prefer to put it that way, Ulrika Karlsson, Chief People Officer and project manager for the SanFranPlan project team, says.

Next steps
The first project meeting will take place at the end of August, and at the moment it’s hard to say how much time each participant will spend on this project.
- Let's say approximately 10-15 project meeting over a year and some work in between, Ulrika estimates. And, of course then, approximately one week research trip to San Francisco later this year, or when appropriate.

When will we all go?

Naturally, this big project will take some time to manage. The provisional date for when will we go on the San Francisco trip all together is currently late 2015 or during 2016. We know that everybody are eager to know. Just stay tuned. More information will follow!

stories.header: Why We Move Towards Simplicity And Smartness And What It Really Means To Our Customers And Our Business
stories.summary: - Simplicity means that we’re aiming to explain our product in an easier way, to take away functionalities that are not needed, and to only add functionalities that are needed when the old functionalities are taken away, Peter Ingman, CEO of Mynewsdesk, explains.
stories.body:
This year, we’re focusing on moving toward simplicity and smartness within Mynewsdesk.

We do that because we’ve seen how the other actors in this field are getting more and more complex, and after careful evaluation, we’ve come to the conclusion that we have been too complex with our product ourselves.

- Simplicity means that we’re aiming to explain our product in an easier way, to take away functionalities that are not needed, and to only add functionalities that are needed when the old functionalities are taken away, Peter Ingman, CEO of Mynewsdesk, explains.

With this reasoning in mind, it means that we don't only strive for simplicity in functions but also in design, user experience and the graphical interface. And the good news are that the product team is already working on those tasks.

What we mean when we say #simplicity
Click on the video below to see Peter Ingman explain what we mean when we talk about simplifying things within Mynewsdesk. 


We're getting smarter
- Regarding the other focus area - smartness - I would say that the 156 of us stand for that smartness, Peter adds. We will use the insights we have in everything we do: from sales to marketing to product development.

- Smartness implies that we will use our numbers, our statistics and our insights to provide a better product to our clients, but also to help our clients to do better communication and to create better content. Everything connected to smartness is a way for us to differentiate us from other tools and competitors, he concludes.

Join the conversation!
Naturally, simplicity and smartness are so many things. What does it mean to you? Join the conversation and feel free to hashtag your own version of #simplicity and #smartness! 

(Peter's Twitter name is @pingman by the way. And you might also want to copy @mndpeople in your message to appear in our newsroom feed.)

Photo credit: Potatojunkie via photopin cc

stories.header: Strategic Plans For Every Team Will Set The Nordics Up For Future Success
stories.summary: - What we want is a clear direction for each and every team, Pär Lagerström, Chief Operating Officer for the Mynewsdesk Nordic organisation, says about this year's strategy work within the Nordic organisation that has resulted in individual strategic plans for the teams in Sweden, Denmark and Norway.
stories.body:
- What we want is a clear direction for each and every team, Pär Lagerström, Chief Operating Officer for the Mynewsdesk Nordic organisation, says about this year's strategy work within the Nordic organisation that has resulted in individual strategic plans for the teams in Sweden, Denmark and Norway. 

Connecting the plans
The Nordics based their strategy plans on the overall company strategy, and started to break it down to fit all levels of the organisation: first to suit the Nordic operations, then on country level and finally for every office and every team. 

- I think it's important for every team to have their own vision connected to the company strategy, Pär states. To achieve that, we have used our company targets, broken them down to action points and then we've answered the question "Why is it important to reach those goals?". 

Including people
Every member of the teams has been involved in the work with the strategic plans. 
- By engaging everyone in this process, we make sure that every employee understands where we as a company are going, and it makes it much easier to create a meaningful working environment, Pär says with confidence. 

He concludes:
- To make sure that the strategic plans become a success, the crucial part is that everyone knows about them. We've actually framed the finished plans, and every team will have them on their wall as a reminder of where they are going. 

The one minute explanation
Watch Pär talk about why the strategic plans should be a working document and how this work supports a learning organisation.

stories.header: Get Ready For One Of The Greatest Projects In Mynewsdesk.com's History
stories.summary: The Funnel team has just started one of the most comprehensive projects in mynewsdesk.com's history. During the next several months, the team consisting of Zoee, Emil, Rei, Ola, and Mike, will redesign the entire public website (everything except the newsrooms and the tool itself), working in structured phases, but releasing each phase globally, rather than using test markets.
stories.body:
There comes a point in a company’s life when you realize that it's time to redesign the website... That time is now.

The Funnel team has just started one of the most comprehensive projects in mynewsdesk.com's history. During the next several months, the team consisting of Zoee, Emil, Rei, Ola, and Mike, will redesign the entire public website (everything except the newsrooms and the tool itself), working in structured phases, but releasing each phase globally, rather than using test markets.

The roadmap is set and they’re almost ready to deliver the first version of the start page and navigation menu for internal release and user testing. Check the video below to find out why and how we're redesigning our website.


During this entire project, you will be updated on a regular basis, right here in the People Newsroom. So stay tuned!

stories.header: Target The Moon. If You Explode On The Way, You'll End Up In The Stars And That's Good Too, Says Mynewsdesker Of The Year.
stories.summary: - The team spirit, both within Mynewsdesk Norway and international, makes it easier to do what you do every day, says Trine Lise Aasgaard Wadoux, winner of the title Mynewsdesker of the Year as well as the best International Sales Person 2013.
stories.body:
- The team spirit, both within Mynewsdesk Norway and international, makes it easier to do what you do every day, says Trine Lise Aasgaard Wadoux, winner of the title Mynewsdesker of the Year as well as the best International Sales Person 2013. 

Trine Lise, who has been working at Mynewsdesk Oslo right from the start three years ago, admits that she didn't had a clue about what Mynewsdesk was when she begun her job.
 
- But being met by this amazing culture and all the fantastic people, I understood that this was a good place to work, she says. 

During the years, she has also developed in her role by first being appointed team leader, and a year later, team manager. 

A true inspiration for others
The nice judgement from the jury when receiving the award Mynewsdesker Of The Year states the following:

For being the best international salesperson at Mynewsdesk for the second year in a row, and always being a true inspiration to others in her daily work.

- I wanted to be one of the best already from the start, so I worked hard to manage to sell Mynewsdesk in Norway, Trine Lise says. It was tough from the beginning but then I simply understood how to do it.

Selling on the Norwegian market
In three years time, the Mynewsdesk product on the Norwegian market has gone from fairly hard to more easy to sell. 

Trine Lise explains why:

- Norwegians are not so happy about changes, she says. But today, when they know who we are, they are more open and do really see the benefits. During these three years I have built up a great network, and can refer to many happy customers, which helps. Nevertheless, since every customer is different, every meeting is still a challenge. 

Reach for the stars!
Watch the video below where Trine Lise talks about how she always targets the moon and don't hesitate to much in her daily life, and why this has made her successful.

stories.header: Top Reasons Why Agencies Should Join Our New Agency Partnership Programme
stories.summary: - As the PR industry adapts to the changing media landscape and the developing trends in digital communications, we've been working with an increasing number of agencies to help them better support their clients. As a result we have decided to make an official offering with the launch our Agency Partnership Programme, Jonathan Bean, Chief Operating Officer at Mynewsdesk, says.
stories.body:
- As the PR industry adapts to the changing media landscape and the developing trends in digital communications, we've been working with an increasing number of agencies to help them better support their clients. As a result we have decided to make an official offering with the launch our Agency Partnership Programme, Jonathan Bean, Chief Operating Officer at Mynewsdesk, says.

- Our tool simply gives them a more efficient and effective way to manage communications on behalf of their clients. It keeps them up to date with the pace of technological development and helps them get the most out of high quality content, including images and videos, he adds.

How to help agencies provide value for their customers
The new programme ensures that agencies worldwide can take advantage of the latest brand newsroom and communications technology to make the most out of these shifts in digital communications. 

- Agencies have always been wonderful at providing strategic advice for their clients as well as managing their content production, distribution and multichannel execution, Jonathan continues. In the video below, he explains why agencies, by providing their clients with the best possible technology in form of a Mynewsdesk newsroom, not only will help their customers to tell their stories in the most effective way but also why the Agency Partnership Programme will be one of our key growth drivers when we continue to develop.  


The newsroom approach
- Agencies are struggling to keep up with the fast paced changing landscape and are employing personell from as many disciplines as possible in order to understand and offer 'expertise' in each field to their clients. Some talk about the newsroom approach and all are aware of the concept but are not able to offer it as a solution. This is where we come in, Nick Osborn, Agency and Partnerships Director at Mynewsdesk UK, says. 

Nick continues:
- The beauty of working with agencies is that word spreads internally and you can end up getting many clients as a result of implementing a newsroom for just one of the brands they work with.

When everyone's a winner
See Jonathan Bean talk about the benefits for agencies when joining the programme, as well as what kind of results our agency partners have seen so far. Also, hear him explain why everyone in this partnership programme is a winner. 


Top reasons why agencies may be interested in getting involved:
  • The potential for increased turnover (one agency has increased their revenue by 30% through working with us)
  • Improved client relationships - our back office eases the content sign off process, is an effective collaboration tool and acts as a hub to store and distribute all of their client's content efficiently and effectively.
  • They can offer online newsroom technology without having to invest in building it themselves. There is also the potential for white labelling.
  • Our team of developers is constantly updating our technology to keep up with trends and improve the product.
  • We can customise our offering to meet their specific needs.
  • We have over 10 years experience in supporting agencies across the globe who look after some of the world's best brands including the likes of Google, Coca-Cola, Toshiba and McDonald's.

stories.header: What Do You Know About The German PR Market? Here Are The Main Things You Should Be Aware Of.
stories.summary: - We are very much at the beginning of the road, but we're working on to be seen as a trusted advisor in the German market, Jürgen Kopelke, Managing Director at Mynewsdesk in Germany, says.
stories.body:
- We are very much at the beginning of the road, but we're working on to be seen as a trusted advisor in the German market, Jürgen Kopelke, Managing Director at Mynewsdesk in Germany, says.

- The PR market in Germany is very conservative, very official. Things change slowly, he adds. It's a very strict industry with a mindset of not wanting to change things that has worked just fine before. 

Helping brands adapt to the new media landscape
But along with the entrance of the social media landscape, even the most traditional businesses need to adapt. 

- Social Media offers a different way of communicating to the public, and along with the trend that budgets are shifted from paid media to earned media, the questions for companies are shifting towards "How can we do that?" and "How can we deal with that?", Jürgen explains. Brands realize they need to create more stories, and tell more about the company, its products, their people and everything they do.

We're Here To Create Something Extraordinary
Watch the video below where Jürgen talks about the PR market in Germany, the potential of Mynewsdesk and how to tweak our red energy to help us to be seen as a trusted advisor on a very formal market.

stories.header: This Award Winning Employee Claims That Capturing Attention Of People Is Like Catching Butterflies
stories.summary: Johan Stam, Sales Representative of the Year at Mynewsdesk, talks about how to capture the attention of people that matter in your business.
stories.body:
As one of the people who have been working at Mynewsdesk for the longest period of time, Johan Stam with his 5 year experience of selling newsrooms was awarded Sales Representative of the Year with the following nice judgement:

For his hard work and loyalty. This guy has really proven that commitment and engagement in the long run leads to excellent sales skills and results. We are really happy that Johan Stam, the one and only, is the 2013 best new biz sales person at Mynewsdesk.

In the video below, Johan explains what made him a winner and how he has built his customer relations over the years.

Catching butterflies
Johan has in a previous story revealed that he’s fond of using case studies and successful press releases from various Mynewsdesk newsrooms to inspire and educate new customers. He also enjoys to paint pictures of how the platform works.  

- Journalists are like butterflies, he says. They’re here and there and everywhere and you’ll never know how to catch them.

He takes this image further to explain what it means to PR professionals:

- Many companies try to catch their butterflies with a tiny butterfly net, running around and swinging it randomly. At best they catch one or two. What I tell them, to explain the value of the Mynewsdesk tool, is that it’s like a huge butterfly net: it allows them to catch all kinds of butterflies, not only the ones they normally chase, and with minimized effort from their side.

Hear Johan describe how to capture the attention of people who matter in this clip:

stories.header: Hear These Employees Explain In Their Own Words What A Mynewsdesk Newsroom Is
stories.summary: But what is a Mynewsdesk newsroom really? Why would PR & marketing professionals need it? And what's so great about it anyway? Good thing we have Catarina, Rebecca, and Teo to answer these questions for us. Have a look at our new video below to learn more about the concept that transformed the PR market when first introduced to the market, and which continues to change the market.
stories.body:
Sometimes the most easy thing is the hardest to explain. At Mynewsdesk, we're really proud of our product, which we've put a lot of effort into making very user friendly, efficient and good looking. 

But what is a Mynewsdesk newsroom really? Why would PR & marketing professionals need it? And what's so great about it anyway? 

Good thing we have Catarina, Rebecca, and Teo to answer these questions for us. Have a look at our new video below to learn more about the concept that transformed the PR market when first introduced to the market more than 10 years ago, and which continues to change the market while constantly being improved since then. 

Basically, the success of the Mynewsdesk platform can be boiled down into the following words, expressed by Teo in the video:
- It's so easy to use because we programmed it that way.

stories.header: Mynewsdesk Labs Just Launched Their First Project
stories.summary: Mynewsdesk exists at the intersection between communications, media and technology which are all industries undergoing considerable structural change. In order to understand and continue being a pioneer in these industries, we wanted to create an autonomous initiative to further learn about what opportunities existed when technology and media come together.
stories.body:
Mynewsdesk and Stampen Sports Media, (one of Sweden’s leading media houses), have initiated a partnership and recently launched the golf site www.golfing.se. The objective with the site is to be the starting place for all Swedish golf enthusiasts, and focus lies on international golf tournament coverage.

- In the start of the third quarter 2013 we wanted to play around with the ideas we had around how to create a new media form inspired by the likes of Flipboard and Zite, who are highly innovative in the news curation and mobile space, Peter Ingman, CEO at Mynewsdesk, explains. A couple of months later in our home market, Omni, a project originated by media group Schibsted was launched publicly, which gave us additional energy to continue our efforts with a similar concept. We also noticed a huge interest from various media houses regarding this. One of those was Stampen, our partner on the newly launched Golfing.se.

What is Mynewsdesk Labs?
Mynewsdesk exists at the intersection between communications, media and technology which are all industries undergoing considerable structural change. In order to understand and continue being a pioneer in these industries, we wanted to create an autonomous initiative to further learn about what opportunities existed when technology and media come together. Aligned with this, we came up with the idea Mynewsdesk Labs, managed by CPO Maja Lindström.

- All individuals at Mynewsdesk are inspired to innovate at all times, but sometimes there's need to allocate time and resources to focus on a specific idea that has popped up somewhere in the organisation, Peter Ingman says. Mynewsdesk Labs is managed by Maja, but the resource allocation of people is done depending on the project at hand.

External partner to co-create the concept
- For this specific project we assigned an external partner, Putget Development, to co-create a new tool and concept together with us, Peter continues. Magnus Enderstein, the CEO, is a friend of mine and we met during his years at Aitellu, a Gothenburg based monitoring company. Magnus moved into our Stockholm office and he run a network of developers from Barcelona to Estonia with the relevant competence and speed necessary to complete this specific effort. In total, six people have been busy with this, including COO Jonathan Bean, and myself.

Platform for future development
As with all innovation within growing technology companies with multiple priorities, it is sometimes necessary to separate off efforts to ensure the core business continues growing strongly, which is happily the case with Mynewsdesk.

- The learnings from this initial project, the collaboration with a major media house and the resulting technology and experience gives us great new opportunities for future developments, Peter Ingman concludes. Mynewsdesk has always advocated that all companies have the opportunity to become media companies. Now we can match that thinking and words with a tangible project which gives us a platform to further develop and innovate at the intersection of communications, media and technology once again.

stories.header: It’s Time For Us To Pioneer The Market Once Again
stories.summary: In Portugal we discussed the need to challenge ourselves by identifying our customer segments’ current pain-points and see if we could be better than everyone else on solving them. GMT believe that we both understand their challenges at hand but that we as a company also have the competence to come up with the best solutions.
stories.body:
I bet you are really interested what we in the Global Management Team really did talk about during our rainy ordeal at the normally so beautiful Algarve coast of Portugal last week. 

This message is one way to disclose some of those really valuable discussions and following decisions that were made. 

First assignment for the GMT was to get rid of all limiting thoughts on what we are and should be offering as the market has changed considerably the last years.

We have over 4,000 customers widely distributed across industries and sizes that are happy with our current offering but waiting for us to take the next move, to once again pioneer this market. 87% of our client base have 1-249 employees. We call this the SMB sector and we believe that these companies have a number of digital challenges that we can help them solve. 

  • Difficult to get noticed and create awareness.
  • Working with limited resources it is hard to keep up with the changes in the marketing landscape. 
  • Knowing what activities work and which don’t.

This is a great opportunity for growing our company globally.

Are we still relevant?
In Portugal we discussed the need to challenge ourselves by identifying our customer segments’ current pain-points and see if we could be better than everyone else on solving them. GMT believe that we both understand their challenges at hand but that we as a company also have the competence to come up with the best solutions. 

The GMT will present more clarity at the All Employee Meeting the 28/4. (Separate invitation will follow). But until then, these are the main decisions we took during the Portugal meeting:

  • Decision 1: build a new offer on our existing product.
  • Decision 2: focus on the SMB sector but lay foundation for a future enterprise offering.
  • Decision 3: create a one-piece content possibility (to develop a better starting point for clients that feel hesitant over their ability to fill a whole newsroom over time).
And yes, we are more relevant to this market than ever before.

All the best, 
Peter

stories.header: Isolation Pushes The Need For New Media, Says Mynewsdesk Pioneer Of The Year
stories.summary: - Mynewsdesk already consists of a lot of pioneers and was founded by pioneers, Christian Mannheimer, Office Manager at the Mynewsdesk Umeå office, says as a reply to winning the title Pioneer Of The Year.
stories.body:
- Mynewsdesk already consists of a lot of pioneers and was founded by pioneers, Christian Mannheimer, Office Manager at the Mynewsdesk Umeå office, says as a reply to winning the title Pioneer Of The Year. 

Now he's officially a member of that leading-edge club. At Mynewsdesk Awards earlier this year, the jury honored him with the following nice judgement: 

"For being a pioneer in opening up the Umeå office. Christian is breaking new ground in the north of Sweden. He and his team are ready to open up the window of Norrland in the Swedish market."

Isolation pushes the need for new media
- Northern companies understand the importance of reaching out, Christian says and points to the fact that isolation creates a higher interest in the new media and its opportunities.

To learn more about the specific conditions Christian is operating within, watch the video below where he talks about the northern market and the pioneering spirit that thrives in the land of the midnight sun.

stories.header: Getting The Right People Onboard Is Crucial Now
stories.summary: - Everyone's calendar is extremely full and we must prioritize every day to focus on what's crucial. The only problem we have is that the sales force is not big enough, Jürgen Kopelke, Managing Director for Mynewsdesk in Germany, states.
stories.body:
- Everyone's calendar is extremely full and we must prioritize every day to focus on what's crucial. The only problem we have is that the sales force is not big enough, Jürgen Kopelke, Managing Director for Mynewsdesk in Germany, states. 

But with no less than eight newcomers onboarding the Mynewsdesk Germany offices this week, the German team is growing exceptionally this spring. But it doesn't end there. 
- Looking at the budget, we should be around 35-40 people working here in Germany at the end of this year, Jürgen says. 

A structure to produce real success in the market
Watch the video below where Jürgen explains the actions he has taken to develop a working structure that sets Mynewsdesk up for success in the German market.

stories.header: The Social Innovation Project Kicks Off Today
stories.summary: - Today is the start-date for our Social Innovation project where we will give away free newsrooms to smaller organisations that can't afford a newsroom themselves, Gabriella Sjödin, Project Manager for the Social Innovation Project at Mynewsdesk, says. The project will go on for a year until April 1st 2015.
stories.body:
- Today is the start-date for our Social Innovation project where we will give away free newsrooms to smaller organisations that can't afford a newsroom themselves, Gabriella Sjödin, Project Manager for the Social Innovation Project at Mynewsdesk, says. The project will go on for a year until April 1st 2015. 

Investing time
There are exciting times ahead. Not only for the chosen organisations, but also for our employees that will engage with a cause they feel passionate about during paid hours for a year. 

- You may use two working days over this period to focus on the social innovation project, Gabriella explains. You're free to distribute the time in a way that best suits you and your organisation, but at least one contact per month with your organisation is mandatory to be able to see that they're using the platform, that they are on track and to collect any questions they have. 

- Also, she says, keep notes of you organisation and the different stages you go through. They can be used later on for external and internal case studies to show how the project proceeded. 

Getting started
Have you contacted your organisation yet? In the video below, Gabriella explains the first steps to take when your organisation has agreed to participate in the project.


How to get started with your chosen organisation:

1. Get to know the organisation
Book a meeting or have a small chat with your chosen organisation for the first phase.

- Get to know the organisation and the person you will have contact with. What are their challenges?- What is happening in the organisation during this year?
- Who are their target groups?
- What do they want to tell or communicate?

This phase is a way for you to get to know the organisation. Remember that you don't need to have all the answers to their problems or questions. On your first meeting, listen to them and write these things down.

Need help presenting Mynewsdesk? Look at the attached document at the bottom of this article. And if it makes you feel more comfortable, ask a colleague within sales/support who are more familiar with the platform to join you in the first meeting.

2. Customer education
Every organisation have the right to get either physical education on the local offices or by telephone. Questions can also be asked to your country manager or your local support team. 

3. Internal Education
This is still in the making but will be presented soon. All employees will get information and tips on how we can think and create a basic PR-plan for our organisations.

stories.header: Brave Dane On His Way To Support The Singapore Office
stories.summary: The brave Mynewsdesk pioneer that will be going to Singapore for a six week secondment will be Nikolaj Skarbye from our Copenhagen office. Nikolai will leave the Danish organisation starting next week for six weeks together with our colleagues in Singapore.
stories.body:
The brave Mynewsdesk pioneer that will be going to Singapore for a six week secondment will be Nikolaj Skarbye from our Copenhagen office. Nikolaj will leave the Danish organisation starting next week for six weeks together with our colleagues in Singapore.

- I hope to improve my understanding of international business and agencies in correlation with their brands, Nikolaj says. I’m for sure looking forward to this great experience and will do my best to reach my targets and support the Asian team.

- I’m also looking forward to become inspired by the city-scape and "big-business" potential down there, he adds.

Secondment assignments
In Singapore, Nikolaj will:

1. Conduct a review of our current client base and ensure they are using Mynewsdesk in the best possible way.

2. Conduct 30 meetings with both existing and new agencies/resellers in Singapore and the region to develop our agency partner and value added resellers program.

3. Coach the existing Mynewsdesk Asia team in the best Mynewsdesk sales techniques.

Success by enthusiasm
The Dane has got some experience of the Asian culture through his interest in a variety of martial arts, ranging from the Japanese aspects of Budo, the Chinese variety of Kung-fu and the Filipino martial arts of stick and knife fighting, (skills he hopefully doesn’t need to practice during the secondment), but has no previous experience of doing business in the region.

- I go with energy and spirit, Nikolaj says. To me it means I have no predetermined boundaries which can block my vision. Businesslike, I think the Danish market is relatively comparable to the Asian markets since we are facing some of the or similar challenges as they are, for example with the stand-alone brand newsroom approach where the client adds their own contacts.

- Nikolaj’s boundless enthusiasm will make sure this will be a real success for both Mynewsdesk Asia and also for his personal development, Jonathan Bean, Chief Operating Officer at Mynewsdesk, states.

stories.header: Embracing The Startup Feeling When Building The German Team
stories.summary: - What Mynewsdesk in Germany offers that is different from other German companies is definitely the cultural part, Anica Herrmann, People Officer, explains. Having a Scandinavian mother company, we have a really special spirit in Mynewsdesk which means that the people are very open, do a lot of things together and share their enthusiasm about things.
stories.body:
- Since we recently opened up the German market with four different offices in Berlin, Leipzig, Hamburg and Munich, we experience a startup feeling all over the company, Anica Herrmann, People Officer in Germany, says.

- What we are doing now is that we're building up the entire German team, she continues. The people we employ are agile, want to move things forward and are eager to establish the business here in Germany. We have a really cool product and it's necessary that we hire people that fit into our pioneering way of thinking about the PR business.  

Scandinavian Culture
- What Mynewsdesk in Germany offers that is different from other German companies is definitely the cultural part, Anica explains. Having a Scandinavian mother company, we have a really special spirit in Mynewsdesk which means that the people are very open, do a lot of things together and share their enthusiasm about things.

Watch the video below to learn more about how it's like working at Mynewsdesk as well as where to go and what to do if you or someone you know are interested in joining our team.

stories.header: We Believe That Programming Is A Social Activity
stories.summary: - What’s most exciting about the Mynewsdesk workplace is that we do pair programming, we always try to change the way we work and that we try to be agile, Kristian Hellquist, Head of Development, says. Now we’re trying out how to work remotely, because that is something that will be of great importance for companies in the future to be able to attract talents from all around the world.
stories.body:
- We probably have one of the largest rails teams in Stockholm, Kristian Hellquist, Head of Development at Mynewsdesk, says. When we’re at meet-ups in Stockholm, we’re definitely the biggest team that work on one product, and as Stockholm is the biggest hub of ruby and rails developers in Sweden, we’re probably the biggest team in Sweden as well.

The developer team in Stockholm contains today of ten rails developers and two frontend developers, who know a bit of rails as well. The company also have two developers in Leipzig.

- We have a very skilled team, Kristian continues, and there is a lot of knowledge and competence sharing within the team.

Pioneering the way we work
- From my perspective, what’s most exciting about the Mynewsdesk workplace is that we do pair programming, we always try to change the way we work and that we try to be agile, Kristian says. Now we’re trying out how to work remotely, because that is something that will be of great importance for companies in the future to be able to attract talents from all around the world.

Three voices
Learn more about the developer team at Mynewsdesk by watching the video below. Listen to David Backéus, Alexander Woll and Kristian Hellqvist talking about team spirit, programming as a social activity and when they do high fives in the office.

stories.header: We're Hunting For Talents That Aren’t Really Looking For A Job
stories.summary: - My main challenge this year is to find candidates that haven’t started their job hunt yet, Ulrika Karlsson, Chief People Officer at Mynewsdesk, says.
stories.body:
- My main challenge this year is to find candidates that haven’t started their job hunt yet, Ulrika Karlsson, Chief People Officer at Mynewsdesk, says.

She continues:
- Employers fight about the best talents, and that’s why it’s better to target and attract a person before they actively begin to search for a new job.

- We recently implemented a career page on LinkedIn to be able to attract candidates right where they are. We know that the people we’re looking for are engaged and active on LinkedIn, maybe not for job search directly but if they would see a really interesting vacancy popping up on their profile, I'm sure they would click it.

- In Germany, most job searchers use Xing, Anica Herrmann, People Officer at Mynewsdesk in Germany, explains. Xing is a similar platform to LinkedIn, and we will have a company profile on Xing up and running during the next weeks that we will use in a similar way for the German market.

Attracting true stars
In today's video, Ulrika Karlsson talks about what types of talents Mynewsdesk are looking for and also gives her advice to those who are interested in joining the Mynewsdesk crew. 

Share the video with those you think would be a perfect match for the Mynewsdesk workplace!

We need your help to find true talents
- There is actually a lot all Mynewsdeskers could do to actually help us find true talents, Ulrika points out. Learn how in the list below. 

  1. Be an ambassador for the Mynewsdesk workplace by updating your LinkedIn or Xing profile. When talents are looking for a job they want to be somewhere where there are other talents, so please make sure you display the workplace on the platform you use. In this way, people who are looking at your profiles will also see a link to our career page.

    For Xing, it's important that all employees use the right company name in their Xing profiles, which is Mynewsdesk GmbH. When you click on the link behind Mynewsdesk GmbH, you will get to the Xing company profile automatically.

  2. Another thing you can do is of course to share our vacancies through social media, or even spread the word in your networks and among family and friends.

  3. Remember that everyone is a headhunter, not only our employees but externals as well! We have something we call the Finders Fee. It means that if you recommend someone to apply for a position at Mynewsdesk and we hire that person, you’ll actually be rewarded with Euro 1.000 for most vacancies like sales persons or others (when they've passed probation). And even better, if you find a developer you'll get a double finders fee (Euro 2.000) because developers are really difficult to find. Send an email to youwilllovethisone@mynewsdesk.com and we'll look that person up.

stories.header: "If Mynewsdesk was a band it would be the Ramones with extra attitude."
stories.summary: As part of being appointed career company of the year by Swedish di.se and Jobtip, we decided to shoot a new video showing what it's like working at Mynewsdesk.
stories.body:
As part of being appointed career company of the year by Swedish di.se and Jobtip, we decided to shoot a new video showing what it's like working at Mynewsdesk. 

The headline above is a quote from the movie, where Robert Stark, business controller and dj, defines Mynewsdesk in terms of music. 

Have a look at the new video below and see how the workplace we've created together rocks! 

Share the red energy
We've uploaded the video to our brand new career page on LinkedIn, to YouTube and to our People Pinterest board as well. The video will also be published to our Career Company Of The Year page on di.se. Feel free to share the Mynewsdesk spirit with everyone that needs a bit of red energy!

stories.header: Brave Enabler Of The Year Will Continue To Take Her Accomplishments To The Next Level
stories.summary: Rebecca Cannerfelt, working with Sales Support and Customer Education at Mynewsdesk Stockholm office, is the winner of the title Brave Enabler Of The Year at the Mynewsdesk Awards that took place in January.
stories.body:
Rebecca Cannerfelt, working with Sales Support and Customer Education at Mynewsdesk Stockholm office, is the winner of the title Brave Enabler Of The Year at the Mynewsdesk Awards that took place in January. 

This is what the jury say about her performance:

"For her very professional and brave enabling way of supporting colleagues and customers, always with that contagious smile of hers. She is a true role model and inspiration."

- I'm a person who likes to try new things, take initiatives, and do my best to deliver more than expected, Rebecca says. In honor of my title, I will continue to do the things I've done in the past year, but take them to the next level. 

Finding energy at work
This brave employee, also rewarded for her wonderful smile, thinks a lot of things make her smile at work.
- Mostly it has to do with all the wonderful colleagues but I also get a lot of energy from the customers, she says. 

In the video below, Rebecca talks about what it's like to be a brave enabler and what winning the title means to her in her professional career. 


This is the first article in a series where all the winners in the Mynewsdesk Awards will be presented. Stay tuned!

stories.header: The Look And Feel Of Mynewsdesk - Our New Brand Book
stories.summary: - Our Mynewsdesk brand is made of many things, Ola Nygren, Head of Design at Mynewsdesk, says. It's the logotype, it's the typography and, most important, it's the people who work here that make up the brand. That's also what we try to emphasize in the new graphic guidelines we've created. We call it our brand book.
stories.body:
- Our Mynewsdesk brand is made of many things, Ola Nygren, Head of Design at Mynewsdesk, says. It's the logotype, it's the typography and, most importantly, it's the people who work here that make up the brand. That's also what we try to emphasize in the new graphic guidelines we've created. We call it our brand book. 

- The brand book is like an organic thing, Joel Helin, Art Director at Mynewsdesk, describes it. This means we have the most necessary ingredients in there, but that it's something that will grow over time. It's more like a guideline rather than something you take literally. 

- We don't want to say this is exactly how a power point presentation or an advert in a newspaper should look like, Ola continues. It's up to the creator to put their own personality in there. People are free to make a great presentation or video or what it might be as long as they get the same feel in their presentation as there is in the brand book.  

In the video below, Ola and Joel talk about the brand book and how to use it when making presentations, videos or other visual materials. 

Have a look at the Brand Book by clicking the attached file below.

comment: Would be interesting to see it. :) Why not share it on Mynewsdesk?
Of course Kay! Thanks for reminding us. I've now attached the Brand Book to this article. Hope you'll find it interesting!

stories.header: Wanted: Brave Mynewsdesker For Three Month Secondment In Singapore
stories.summary: As part of the international development of Mynewsdesk, an exciting opportunity has arisen for a three month secondment to our Singapore office.
stories.body:
As part of the international development of Mynewsdesk, an exciting opportunity has arisen for a three month secondment to our Singapore office.

- The overall goal of this project is to support our Asian business and provide a key personal development opportunity to one lucky Mynewsdesker, says Jonathan Bean, Chief Operating Officer.

This project role is open to anyone already working at Mynewsdesk with Sales/Marketing or Customer Success experience who wants to broaden their insight into international business development in one of the fastest growing markets in the world. The secondment is due to run for a maximum of three months from March 20th to June 20th.

- Following this period you will return to your original position at Mynewsdesk but with a much broader understanding of our global opportunities, Mr Bean concludes.

The specific activities and goals for this project include:

  • Meeting with and analyzing the present and future needs of our existing client base.
  • Business development with the agency community in Singapore to further promote
  • Mynewsdesk's - Agency Partner Program.
  • Supporting Existing Activities - including industry and product training of Mynewsdesk's existing reseller Network (Japan, Hong Kong, Korea, Indonesia, Thailand).
  • Exchanging PR & Content Marketing best practice among Asia Communicators.
  • Exchanging Sales & Marketing best practices from Mynewsdesk's European markets with the Mynewsdesk Asia Team.
  • Supporting Existing Activities - including industry and product training of Mynewsdesk's existing reseller Network and sales to qualified leads generated by the current marketing activities.

How to apply

For additional questions, please contact Ulrika Karlsson or Jonathan Bean.

Send your application to ulrika.karlsson@mynewsdesk.com the 4th of March at the latest.

stories.header: Mynewsdesk Director of Agencies & Partnerships Thinks 2014 Is The Year Of The Newsroom
stories.summary: - It’s strange to walk into a place where people are genuinely happy and the weeks are going so quickly, says Nick Osborn, new hire and the Director of Agencies & Partnerships at the Mynewsdesk London office.
stories.body:
- It’s strange to walk into a place where people are genuinely happy and the weeks are going so quickly, says Nick Osborn, new hire and the Director of Agencies & Partnerships at the Mynewsdesk London office.

He’s clearly enthusiastic about his new workplace and co-workers:

- When I came to Sweden for the Academy introduction program, everyone there were so friendly. They were just lovely, just natural down to earth, naturally enthusiastic and they really wanted to make a difference, he states.

Geared Up For Success
Specifically handling UK agencies and partnerships, Nick will focus on building great relationships with relevant associations to target where we should be pushing and educating our audience.

-Everything at Mynewsdesk is really geared up to make the whole thing a success, he says. Everyone is on board, all work together, everyone has got such great ideas, and everyone is so creative.

The Year Of The Newsroom
Watch Nick in the video below, talking about his impressions of the Mynewsdesk brand, people and product as well as why he thinks 2014 is The Year Of The Newsroom.

stories.header: How Mynewsdesk Helped Eurofound To Better Understand Their Audience
stories.summary: Måns Mårtensson, Media Manager at Eurofound, gives his thoughts on how Mynewsdesk has helped him to better understand and engage with his targeted audience.
stories.body:
- 2014 is all about targeting for us, Måns Mårtensson, Media Manager at Eurofound and Mynewsdesk customer, points out. We are trying to consolidate all the contacts that we have. Our main goal is to reach European social policy makers and to give them what they want, when they need it and in a format that they can use.

How to get a story across
Eurofound is an European organization dealing with socio-economic research. They cover all the member states plus the candidate countries in the European Union and are often doing their survey work in 32-33 countries.

- To get that across in a research report is sometimes quite boring, and it’s also quite tricky, Måns says. He continues:

- There’s where tech comes in. Mynewsdesk is going to help me engage with new audiences; with people that are writing and engaging in and around the topics we study and focus on, and to help us really broaden and reaching out to a wider audience.

Måns' thoughts on Mynewsdesk
Last week, we had the pleasure to meet Måns at the Mynewsdesk London office. In the video below, he gives his thoughts on how Mynewsdesk has helped him to better understand and engage with his targeted audience.

stories.header: We Will Continue To Surprise The Market With New Ways Of Doing Things
stories.summary: - We are coming from the PR side, but a lot of changes have taken place in our industry, says Peter Ingman, CEO of Mynewsdesk. New buzzwords arose in 2013 and we clearly moved the needle within thought leadership as we actively participated talking about the Brand Newsroom.
stories.body:
- We are coming from the PR side, but a lot of changes have taken place in our industry, says Peter Ingman, CEO of Mynewsdesk. New buzzwords arose in 2013 and we clearly moved the needle within thought leadership as we actively participated talking about the Brand Newsroom.

- We also know that our competitors are shifting towards content marketing, which is an immensely bigger market than PR (40 billion dollar compared to 2.2 billion dollar). When marketeers are allocating their budgets for the new year, we will probably see how advertisement numbers are decreased in favor of content marketing but also investments by brands to have their own content hub.

- Mynewsdesk as a company is perfectly positioned for this development, Peter says. We have great knowledge of PR and media relations, but as we are part of a big media house, we're now betting on brand journalism to help our clients produce relevant and engaging content.

The question Why
- The questions we have been most preoccupied with during the past months have been what we are and where we are going, he continues. Today, most of us talk about our PR platform, but room for service offerings could be widened. Lately, the General Management Team have been discussing this. We've been asking ourselves why we are in business and how we do business.

- We believe that true enthusiasm for a brand can only be earned and never bought, Peter explains. We are here to help organisations reach out to and earn that respect from those that matter most to them.

- We also define the way how we do business as that our products and our people always aim to bring simplicity to the daily work of communication professionals. We help them create genuine engagement with their audience so they might succeed far beyond their own expectations. And as the world around us change, we always challenge ourselves to come up with better solutions.

We protect our core while we develop the future
- Our efforts are now focused even more on understanding and delivering services that cater for the future, Peter Ingman says. In this intriguing industry, one of the two things we need to do is protect the core, as in keeping the love of our customers. We will build upon our strengths and keep improving the product. Examples of these efforts are our new Analyze tool and our Customer Success Initiative, and we will allocate more resources here.

- We will also develop the future, as we have always done, he continues. We as a company always strive to lead market changes instead of just adapt to them. Our business strategy requires us to be agile, dare to try out new functions and be able to turn very quickly. We will continue to surprise the market with new ways of doing things.

The Focus areas for 2014 (read where we re-invest all the money) are:

  1. Customer Success has always been at our core, but even more so we have positioned this specifically for reaching even higher levels.

  2. Product Development means adding resources, improve and build for the future, integrate current and grow more fun lab initiatives. The Content Creation module is one of them.

  3. Marketing Sales Funnel. To get real value from our efforts to see the whole process through.

  4. Reseller program. Finland gave us great insights in how to become successful with a trusted partner. We have no plans to grow with new offices this year, however optimize our customer acquisition through a well supported reseller program. The advantage would be that it gives us more effective scalability but with a lower risk. This is the reason why Peter is going to Brazil within two weeks.

Our main targets are:

1) Employee Satisfaction. We strive to stay on a 90 % level in the employee satisfaction survey. We will further develop our creative and fun workplace with inspiring colleagues and a meaningful purpose. Our Social Innovation Project is a good example and it's a great possibility to really do some good for others. We have already received a lot of positive feedback both internally and from our stakeholders. The Social Innovation Project also builds reputation and respect in the market, as well as develops ourselves to become broader and even more skilled in modern comms practice.

2) Loyal customers. We aim to maintain the level of keeping 9 out of 10 customers.

3) Growth. We are proud for our sound business model and our ability to be profitable and still grow. But most of our competitors have the luxury with a lot of cash to invest for quicker expansion. Our owners NHST have therefore approved an investment budget in order to provide a strong vehicle for strong long term growth over the coming years.
