stories.header: Mynewsdesk Dev Team Arranged Meetup For Berlin’s Developer Communities
stories.summary: - We aim to establish ourselves as a driving force in Berlin’s Ruby and Front-end developer communities. That’s why we flew down the entire developer team from the Stockholm office for an open Dev Corner in Berlin last week, says Teo Ljungberg, Developer at Mynewsdesk in Stockholm. A Dev Corner is our internal team-conference where we share ideas and new technologys, he adds.
stories.body:
- We aim to establish ourselves as a driving force in Berlin’s Ruby and Front-end developer communities. That’s why we flew down the entire developer team from the Stockholm office for an open Dev Corner in Berlin last week, says Teo Ljungberg, Developer at Mynewsdesk in Stockholm. A Dev Corner is our internal team-conference where we share ideas and new technologys, he adds.

Another reason for the Berlin event was to form a network of skilled developers, as Mynewsdesk is looking at setting up a development team also in Berlin.

Meet & Greet At The Mynewsdesk Berlin Office
With some help of free beer and pizza, the Dev Corner attracted about 25 German developers that managed to arrive at the Mynewsdesk Berlin-Kreutzberg office despite of an unexpected snowstorm.

- During the event, we mingled and listened to a few presentations, Teo says. The participants gave us great feedback on how much fun they had and how cool it was to fly down the entire team to Berlin for a meetup. There are quite a few startups in Berlin, like Soundcloud and 6 Wunderkinder, which program in Ruby and Ruby on Rails, but the developer communities in Berlin are small and dense and that’s why we’re pondering on starting our own developers community in Berlin, as we have in Stockholm.

Knowledge Sharing At Work
Being the largest Ruby team in Sweden, there’s a huge learning potential for the Mynewsdesk developers while being at work.

- Pair programming is the way we go, Teo Ljungberg explains. Two brains are always smarter than one and as you need to explain your ideas and describe the problem, there’s an extremely favorable learning environment to be around. And personally, Teo adds, I enjoy working together with someone rather than sitting alone.

The job situation at Mynewsdesk is also appealing.
- Being a product centric company, we never just receive an order to do something but are always asked what we think, Teo explains. That’s why we call ourselves developers rather than programmers.

He continues:
- We’re always free to try out new things, and two days per month we have lab days where we can work on anything we like.

Wanna see for yourself what happens at a Dev Corner? Flip through the flickr album below or search for the hashtag #mnddc.


Photo credit: joakwest, hilladuka and flisanberglund on Instagram.

stories.header: 2013: Our Year Of Change
stories.summary: - 2013 has been a year full of major challenges, says Peter Ingman, CEO of Mynewsdesk. Not only have we gone through a change organizationally, but a huge market change has also taken place.
stories.body:
- 2013 has been a year full of major challenges, says Peter Ingman, CEO of Mynewsdesk. Not only have we gone through a change organizationally, but a huge market change has also taken place.

He points out:

- Looking at the market, it's full of communicators that investigates the new possibilities with content marketing, questioning the old way to do PR but still demands effective reach to journalists. 

- Internally, this was a year with quite some degrees of uncertainty, Peter continues. We knew that changes would take place due to the ownership model, but it happened earlier than anticipated. That means that we have developed a new management structure. We now have all key positions in place, as well as a dedicated General Management Team, and that made it possible for us to continue our international expansion.

- We succeeded last year in continued growth whilst being profitable, due to loyal customers, successfully delivered record sales numbers and we also reached an ambitious budget, Peter explains. Mynewsdesk has 4,000 customers and manage over 5,000 newsrooms. The customers are very loyal and 9 of 10 stay with the company.

stories.header: Meet The Winners Of Mynewsdesk Awards
stories.summary: Mynewsdesk Awards were announced on Monday during the All Employee Meeting. Eleven remarkable Mynewsdeskers were recognized for their extraordinary achievements during the year.
stories.body:
Mynewsdesk Awards were announced on Monday during the All Employee Meeting. Eleven remarkable Mynewsdeskers were recognized for their extraordinary achievements during the year.

The title Mynewsdesker of the Year is based on employee votes. In the other four categories, the General Management Team acted as the deciding force among the nominees. Account Manager of the Year (Sweden) and Sales Representative of the Year (International & Sweden) are based on sales figures only.

Ladies and gentlemen, we proudly present… (drumroll)...

Johan Stam - Sales Representative of the Year
For his hard work and loyalty. This guy has really proven that commitment and engagement in the long run leads to excellent sales skills and results. We are really happy that Johan Stam, the one and only, is the 2013 best new biz sales person at Mynewsdesk.

Fredrik Ånebrink - Account Manager of the Year
This professional Account Manager has reach excellent results due to his wonderful skills in sales and relationship building. With a smile he is always ready to inspire the next customer. 

Daniel Pichel - Web Enthusiast of the Year
For taking on the journey from PHP to Ruby but more importantly for maintaining and developing five different platforms as well as starting to build to MND Networked future. This man has gone from blue to truly red in 12 months.

Rebecca Cannerfelt - Brave Enabler of the year
For her very professional and brave enabling way of supporting colleagues and customers, always with that contagious smile of hers. She is a true role model and inspiration.

Christian Mannheimer - Pioneer of the Year
For being a Pioneer in opening up the Umeå Office. Christian is breaking new ground in the north of Sweden. He and his team is ready to open up the window of Norrland in the Swedish market.

Jonas Cohn - Openness of the Year
For being a very professional and experienced Key Account Manager always open and very helpful sharing his knowledge with other colleagues to help them improve and develop.

Hilla Duka - Mynewsdesker of the Year
For her unique combination of deep technical knowledge of our product and her compassion and curiosity for our customers needs makes her an important key to building the right product for our market. Hilla has gone from being a rising star to a solid rock we all can rely on. 

Sylvia Eberl - Mynewsdesker of the Year
For her talent for relationship building and deep knowledge of PR and journalism in Germany and for the fact that over 40% of all MND Germany revenue has been generated by this Munich red hero. She is truly amazing.

Heather Athie - Mynewsdesker of the Year
For creating the Account Management, Retention and Customer Success team in one of Mynewsdesk's most challenging markets and getting results. Heather combines engagement, insight and humour which makes both her customers and her colleagues delighted.

Nikolaj Skarbye - Mynewsdesker of the Year
For his engagement and hard work in the Danish market. He has shown us how to break ice in one very though market. Looking at his activities he is a true inspiration to every sales person at Mynewsdesk.

Trine-Lise Wadoux - Mynewsdesker of the Year
For being the best international salesperson at Mynewsdesk for the second year in a row, and always being a true inspiration to others in her daily work. 

Each winner will be further presented in an in-depth interview during the coming year.

stories.header: 9 Out Of 10 Think That Mynewsdesk Is A Great Place To Work
stories.summary: Based on the results from our yearly employee satisfaction survey, it seems like the employees at Mynewsdesk are happier with their immediate manager than before. Leadership is the main area where we as a company has improved in the survey this year, and we can see that there is an average improvement of 23 percentage points on the questions regarding the immediate manager.
stories.body:
Based on the results from our yearly employee satisfaction survey, it seems like the employees at Mynewsdesk are happier with their immediate manager than before. Leadership is the main area where we as a company has improved in the survey this year, and we can see that there is an average improvement of 23 percentage points on the questions regarding the immediate manager. 

Everything taken into account, I think this is a great place to work

What's also very positive, is that 90 percent of the Mynewsdesk employees think that this is a great place to work. The same number last year was 86 percent and our target for 2013 was 89 percent. 

Looking at the individual markets, there's an even higher result in the UK. 95 percent of the employees agree on that Mynewsdesk is a great place to work. (Read more about what Peter Britton, manager of the UK team, thinks of happy work experiences and team motivation by clicking the links). 

We are not yet among the top ten employers in the study, but we are for sure closing in as we are just 5-10 percentage points below the top results. 

These are the top 3 results for Mynewsdesk in the survey:

  • I can be myself around here. (95% agree)
  • People care about each other. (93% agree)
  • My immediate manager recognizes honest mistakes as part as doing business. (92% agree)
The GMT Promise

There are only two questions that have a result where most of the employees agree that this is not completely true. These are the lowest results in the survey:

  • The management team has a clear view of where the organization is going and how to get there. (40% agree)
  • I feel I receive a fair share of the profits made by this organization. (48% agree)
- We're not surprised that people are questioning the ability of management to present a clear view of the direction of the company, says Peter Ingman, CEO of Mynewsdesk. The truth is that we don't always have a ready-made map that tells us where we're going. The industry is constantly changing and as we always strive to lead that change instead of just adapt to it, our strategy is more about discovering instead of setting up a long-term plan and stick to it no matter what. Our business strategy requires us to be agile, dare to try out new functions and be able to turn very quickly. But we should have been better at communicating just that.

-It's clear that the general management team has a communication lesson to learn, Peter continues. The promise from the GMT for the new year is to become much better in communicating the company's turns and also how we invest our profit. The All Employee Meeting earlier this week was part of that effort, and even more focus will be put on explaining the operations in the future.

stories.header: How To Make People Relax In Front Of The Camera
stories.summary:
- The key to success when making a corporate video is to make people feel relaxed in front of the camera, says Frida Öjstrand, intern at the Mynewsdesk UK office and specialized in video creation. 

This story gives you practical advice on how to make people relax in front of the camera.
stories.body:
When the Danish prime minister Helle Thorning-Schmidt took a selfie with Barack Obama and David Cameron at Nelson Mandela's memorial, she shook the world. People raged against it and the action has been called all kinds of stuff. "Selfie-gate", "selfish" and "the world's worst selfie" are just some of it. 

One thing is clear: the picture taken by the three world leaders is as interesting as the phenomena itself. "Selfie" is the word of the year according to the Oxford Dictionaries, and taking photos of oneself (and uploading them on social media) engages people of all ages, sexes and cultures. 

Still, many people are uncomfortable in front of the camera, especially when it comes to corporate video and photo shoots. 

 

Last week, Frida Öjstrand, intern at the Mynewsdesk London office, visited Stockholm to video record the crew for her Mynewsdesk employee movie. She managed to squeeze in about 15 interviews with the Swedish co-workers. 

- The key to success when making a corporate video is to make people feel relaxed in front of the camera, Frida says. The more comfortable people are, the better the outcome. 

During Frida's video shoot, she was assisted by Mike Rooseboom, product marketing, and Anna Rydne, internal communication. The three made some awesome interviews during the days, and the team now shares their best tips on how to make people comfortable in front of the camera. 

Frida

  • Try to engage in good dialogue with your interview person. If you’re able to make them forget about the camera, your clip will look more natural and relaxed.
  • Ask the person you are going to interview to put on clothes they’re comfortable with. If the person doesn’t feel at ease with their appearance, it’ll show in the video.
  • Change environment! Find another place than in the middle of the office space. It’s great to go to a cafe and tape the interview over a cup of coffee.
  • Appear calm and happy when you’re doing the interview. Make the person feel that they know their stuff.

Mike


  • Tell them a joke or get them to tell a joke.
  • Start off by asking them to talk informally about themselves.
  • Tell them "Don't worry, we cut out the bad parts and edit the film to only show the good parts" even if it's a lie!
  • Lighting is key.
  • Ask them to jump up and down 5 times to loosen up.
  • Start by doing the parts that don't require them looking straight into the camera (interview shots, action shots, etc).
  • Do a practice run first.
  • Take a break if it's a longer session or if you notice the quality diminishing or nervousness increasing.

Anna


  • Don't let your interview person wait for long in front of the camera while you're fiddling with the video equipment. Keep the conversation flowing while you're doing it and don't allow any time where they may get nervous. Chitchat in a friendly way, make jokes and show them that you really care about getting the best out of them.
  • Turn the bloopers into something fun. Have patience and laugh about them. 
  • Listen carefully to their answers and ask follow up questions to bring out the best quotes.
  • Tell them that you can make them look even more handsome in the movie editor. (It's actually true!)

Photo credits: AFP, coskills, mike_rooseboom, fridaojstrand

stories.header: Mynewsdesk Awards: It’s Time To Nominate The Best Of The Best
stories.summary: Who do you think has achieved something extraordinary within our company during the year? Who has fought and won the toughest challenges? And who lived our values while doing so? What name pops up in your head? Who better than anyone deserves public praise for their efforts? Give recognition and nominate a co-worker or two, (or even nine if you feel like it), to the Mynewsdesk Awards 2013.
stories.body:
Who do you think has achieved something extraordinary within our company during the year? Who has fought and won the toughest challenges? And who lived our values while doing so?

What name pops up in your head? Who better than anyone deserves public praise for their efforts?

Don’t just think the name. Give recognition and nominate a co-worker or two, (or even nine if you feel like it), to the Mynewsdesk Awards 2013.

The categories
We have seven categories to reward, and you may nominate people to five of them.

  • Mynewsdesker of the Year: this can be a person who has done something remarkable, someone who deserves recognition, someone who has done something we shall all be proud of, someone who has worked very hard without much acknowledgement or someone who has helped someone out in an outstanding way. Only you know the criteria to be applied in this category. Let us know!
  • Pioneer of the Year: Someone who is innovative, takes own initiatives and actions as well as being business oriented in a way that they make sure their actions contribute to our company goals.
  • Brave Enabler of the Year: Someone who questions status quo, who leads by example by being genuine and being themselves as well as someone who dares to fail.
  • Web Enthusiast of the Year: Someone who dares to try new ways of working with the web to improve their work, who chooses digital over analog when it is more effective, stays up to date with industry news and keep themselves informed about what is going on at Mynewsdesk.
    • Openness of the Year: Someone who shares knowledge and experiences, is honest and sincere, open to change and new ideas as well as being service minded and caring.

(The title Mynewsdesker of the Year is based on employee votes only. In the other four categories above, the General Management Team act as the deciding force among the nominees).

Two categories are based on sales figures only:

  • Account Manager of the Year (Sweden)
  • Sales Representative of the Year (International & Sweden)

How to nominate
It’s easy. Just send an email to awards@mynewsdesk.com and spell out your reason why the person is a worthy winner for the chosen category. Make sure to press the send button before December 17th.

The winners
The winners will be presented at our All Employee Meeting on January 17th. Aside from having their diploma nailed to the Stockholm HQ wall of fame and being interviewed for our People newsroom, the winners will also get the opportunity to educate themselves further and develop their specific skills together with other key persons in the company during the coming year. You’ll get more details on the prizes further on, but we’ll guarantee you that no one will be disappointed!

stories.header: A Great Place To Work: Time For The Annual Employee Workplace Survey
stories.summary: We want Mynewsdesk to continue to be a great place to work, and to help us on this journey, we are for the third time carrying out an extensive yearly employee survey in collaboration with the external supplier Great Place to Work.
stories.body:
In continuous surveys during the year, we’ve been pleased to learn that a steady 86 percent of the employees at Mynewsdesk around the globe agree on the question “Taking everything into account, I would say this is a great place to work”.

Improving our future
We want Mynewsdesk to continue to be a great place to work, and to help us on this journey, we are for the third time carrying out an extensive yearly employee survey in collaboration with the external supplier Great Place to Work. We see it as a means to identify what works well and what needs to be improved in our workplace.

- The purpose of the survey is to collate a snap-shot view of how the organisation works today so that we can use this information to improve in the future, says Ulrika Karlsson, Chief People Officer at Mynewsdesk. In order to do this we need the help of every employee. Everyone’s feedback is critical!

- The survey is also a great tool for every leader to receive open and honest feedback on the leadership. I am myself really looking forward to it, even though I continuously ask for feedback from my employees, Ulrika continues. We know for a fact that the most important factor that affect employee satisfaction and performance is the leadership.

Next steps
As a Mynewsdesk employee, you will receive an invitation to the survey by email on December 4th, sent to you from Great Place To Work. By completing the survey promptly, honestly and sincerely you will help us to identify how we can improve.

Please note that the survey is designed so that it is impossible to identify individuals. Your answers are completely anonymous.

The survey results will be presented in January and you will get further opportunity to discuss the results at department level in your regular team meetings.

stories.header: Mynewsdesk Launches Their Social Innovation Project
stories.summary: - People want to do good stuff, says Peter Ingman, CEO and founder of Mynewsdesk. During the years, we’ve seen that many large non-profit organizations have reached and exceeded their goals when using our newsrooms. That’s why we thought: “hey, how cool wouldn’t it be if we give that opportunity to passionate and driven smaller help organizations as well?!”.
stories.body:
Our Social Innovation Project (formerly known as the Corporate Responsibility Program) is moving forward behind the scenes of Mynewsdesk.

It’s now decided that each employee will get the opportunity to pick and choose a charity they feel passionate about, and work with that organization during a year, helping them to receive the best possible attention for their specific cause.

- People want to do good stuff, says Peter Ingman, CEO and founder of Mynewsdesk. During the years, we’ve seen that many large non-profit organizations have reached and exceeded their goals when using our newsrooms. That’s why we thought: “hey, how cool wouldn’t it be if we give that opportunity to passionate and driven smaller help organizations as well?!”.

- Giving away one newsroom for every employee is a way where we as a company will be able to do something good that engage our staff, Peter continues. In a fast growing company, it’s important to do things that bring people together. At the same time, we train all of our employees, regardless of position, to explore the benefits of our newsrooms and to find new methods to exploit them in the most innovative and effective ways possible. This knowledge will be beneficial to all our existing clients as well.

Learn more about the Social Innovation Project in the video below where Peter Ingman gives further insights why we’re doing this and also explains how we engage all our 150 employees in such an ambitious project. 

Stay tuned >> We'll get back to you with more information on how to select a charity within shortly.

comments.comment: I already have one in mind! =) Excited.

stories.body:

International Runner-up’s

These people sure know how to keep a customer happy! Feel free to copy the best of the best.

Mynewsdesk Awards

As we’re approaching the Mynewsdesk Awards 2013, it’s time for everyone to step up a gear to catch up with the leaders on the board above.

For you who don’t work in sales, there are other exciting categories to strive for. How about theMynewsdesker of the year? Or perhaps some of the following:

  • Openness of the year
  • Pioneer of the year
  • Web-enthusiast of the year
  • Brave enabler of the year

There will also be a team prize and a prize for best account manager.

We’ll get back to you soon with some more information about the nomination process. Stay tuned!

stories.header: #mnday Trended On Twitter
stories.summary: As the second most mentioned hashtag, #mnday rocked Sweden for at least 14 hours during Tuesday 8th and Wednesday 9th of October. How come that #mnday got such a reach? Read the story.
stories.body:
Since Mynewsdesker Robin Tuorda first mentioned the hashtag #mnday on his Twitter timeline, it took 134 users, 214 mentions and 44 retweets during seven days to make it into a Trending Topic in Sweden.

As the second most mentioned hashtag, (higher rank than the #NobelPrize, despite being in the middle of the prize’s announcement week), #mnday rocked Sweden for at least 14 hours during Tuesday 8th and Wednesday 9th of October.

How come that #mnday got such a reach?

Let’s ask Hilla Duka, Product Owner at Mynewsdesk and Chief Tweeting Officer at Mynewsday in Stockholm. Hilla managed the Twitter account during the day, and her main responsibilities was to cover the talks, and monitor and reply to audience reactions and questions.

#mnday was trending on Twitter as the second most popular hashtag. What’s your reaction to that?
- I think it’s amazing, though not surprising. There were loads of people tweeting, and you could really tell that the message from the talks resonated with the audience.

Which one of the lecturers got the most reactions?
- I would probably say it was a tie between Renata Chlumska and Catarina Clöwe. Everyone were so energized, impressed and enthused by Renata’s talk, her energy really took hold. Then Catarina came on, and the tweeters just fell completely for her honesty and courage. They both had great stage presence and their talks resonated with people.

What was the most challenging about tweeting live at the Mynewsday event?
- I’m not an avid tweeter, the whole experience of tweeting from an event was new to me, so just trying to listen to all the interesting talks, and at the same time tweet something intelligent was quite a challenge.

What was the most memorable thing that happened during the Twitter session?
- I was really impressed with the quality of the tweets from the audience. It’s so hard to live tweet, and yet so many people managed to capture perfectly a phrase or a point. There were so many clever, articulate people in the audience. I just wanted to retweet what they said!

Photo credits: hilladuka.se

stories.header: A Change Of Language In The Stockholm Office
stories.summary:
Yu Wang is our newest hire at Mynewsdesk in Sweden. With a passion for technology, he’s one of the shining stars in the R&D department. He’s also our first non-swedish speaking employee.

Having Yu onboard means that we’ll switch Swedish into English as the official language in our Stockholm office.
stories.body:
Yu Wang is our newest hire at Mynewsdesk in Sweden. With a passion for technology, he’s one of the shining stars in the R&D department. He’s also our first non-swedish speaking employee.

Having Yu onboard means that we’ll switch Swedish into English as the official language in our Stockholm office.

“This is no drastic change. Being a global company with fellow Mynewsdeskers in all the Scandinavian countries, UK, Germany and Singapore, everyone of our employees are used to speak English when colleagues from different countries meet and interact. But what’s novel about the hire of Yu is that we’re now international even on a local level and will communicate only in English in all internal emails and office meetings as well”, says Anna Rydne, internal communicator at Mynewsdesk.

About Yu

Originally from China, Yu started his career at Ericsson in Shanghai, but decided to go to Sweden 3,5 years ago to study for a Masters Degree in Software Engineering at KTH in Stockholm.

At Mynewsdesk Yu will work as a Ruby on Rails-developer.

“I like to build new things and implement them”, he says.

He also loves to swim and travel. This globetrotter spends his holidays traveling and have visited two European countries every year since he moved to Sweden.
